title: Spending & Saving Styles
description: Discover how you each relate to money and what that means for your partnership.

questions.text: When it comes to money, I'm more of a...
choices: Saver - security feels good
Spender - experiences matter more than savings
Planner - I like knowing where it all goes
Relaxed - I don't think about it much

therapeutic.rationale: Our money personality forms early and runs deep. Understanding each other's baseline orientation helps you anticipate how you'll navigate finances together—whether that's splitting a dinner bill or buying a house someday.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Saver-spender pairs are common and can balance each other beautifully—or drive each other crazy. The key is seeing your partner's style as a strength, not a flaw.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared money styles make some things easier, but watch for blind spots. Two savers may forget to enjoy; two spenders may need external guardrails.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What's your earliest memory about money? How do you think it shaped your approach today?

questions.text: If we were planning something expensive together, I'd want us to...
choices: Research and compare options thoroughly first
Talk through what matters most to each of us
Have whoever cares more take the lead
Decide spontaneously when it feels right

therapeutic.rationale: How you'd approach a big decision together reveals expectations about teamwork, control, and communication—before any money is actually involved.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different approaches aren't dealbreakers—they're data. The researcher can gather info while the talker ensures both voices are heard. Name your preferences early.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared decision-making styles make future choices smoother. But even aligned couples benefit from occasionally stretching into the other's approach.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Think of a decision you made together (any size). What worked about how you approached it?

questions.text: When it comes to treating each other, I believe...
choices: We should split things fairly
Whoever has more should treat more often
Taking turns feels right
It shouldn't matter—we're a team

therapeutic.rationale: Attitudes about who pays reveal deeper beliefs about fairness, generosity, and partnership. There's no right answer, but unspoken assumptions cause friction.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different views on treating can create awkwardness or resentment if unspoken. Have the conversation before it becomes a pattern that bothers someone.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared beliefs make this easy—but circumstances change. Check in as your situations evolve.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you feel when your partner pays for you? How about when you pay for them?

questions.text: Something I'd want us to be aligned on financially is...
choices: How much to save vs. spend on experiences
Being open about what we earn and owe
What we're each comfortable spending without checking in
Long-term goals, even if they're far off

therapeutic.rationale: This reveals what financial alignment means to you—and it varies widely. Some need transparency; others need autonomy; others need shared dreams. Knowing your partner's priority helps you build trust in the right currency.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different priorities aren't conflict—they're a roadmap for conversations to have. Both matter; tackle them in order of urgency for your stage.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared priority gives you a clear starting point. Build alignment there first, then expand.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What would make you feel like true financial partners? What's the first conversation you'd need to have?

questions.text: The money conversation I'd most like us to have is about...
choices: What we each learned about money growing up
Dreams or goals we haven't fully talked through yet
How we're really feeling about where we are financially
Something we've been avoiding or tiptoeing around

therapeutic.rationale: Every couple—new or established—has money conversations they haven't had yet. Naming the one you want invites your partner into deeper territory, whether that's first-time sharing or long-overdue honesty.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different desired conversations reveal different needs. One may want to understand history; another may want to address tension. Both are valid—take turns.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared desire points to a conversation you're both ready for. Have it soon.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What money conversation have you been wanting to have but haven't? What's held you back?
